body: Do we want to bump the whole project to 2.10?
Oop. No. That's a left over until Finatra is dual published.

Ship It!

lgtm

Most of our storage backends don't really support it, so you'd probably have to write an alternate indexer to do this.  It might be interesting to use something like Elasticsearch for indexing and then proxy through to the actual storage layer.  Or use Elasticsearch for the whole thing.  We don't have any plans for any of this though.
shipit

Pulled Finatra entirely as a dependency. Zipkin Web thus takes control of its own destiny regarding Scala, Finagle, Mustache, and Jackson versions.

Finatra is still basically a side project, it doesn't have dedicated support. We (temporarily) lose some flexibility at development time due to resource caching, but that can be fixed. Endpoints are now simple Finagle Services with composed with Filters. Multiplexing is done with HttpMuxer. There might be a better way to organize the endpoints. I'll keep experimenting.
Thank you.
This seems useful to me and not a big change code/ui wise from what I can tell. I'll let someone that knows front end stuff chime in though.
I'm surprised none of these other storages like redis and cassandra have Closable compatible close methods.

Seems reasonable.  Perhaps we can trim the decimal precision down a bit though?
I'll let @sprsquish chime in though.  What about making this a tooltip?
Redis and Cassie are behind the times, by quite a bit. They don't implement Closable, yet. And updating them isn't a yak I want to shave just yet.

I played with this a little. I like the idea, but think it needs a bit more. Having the extra line only gives a sense of what's happening but no real data is provided. 

What about @bmdhacks' suggestion of a tooltip? Add a little popover that provides the timing breakdowns?

I am not attached to the current approach and I'm willing to try out other ways to visualize this. I do think that it should be readily apparent and not hidden in a tool tip (you can already click the span to see the actual timestamps).

Inspiration from the Dapper paper:

```
Every RPC span is broken down further into time spent within a server
process (green) and time spent on the network (blue).
```

![dapper example](http://f.cl.ly/items/1T0r3g3v0S3R2f1Q242q/dapper-2.png)
God I want that +- thread expansion, not the janky pseudo-intellijent fake-spans we have now.
Is this the desired solution: all services convert the date to a fixed time zone, such as UTC+00:00 time zone, and then store the long-type date (e.g. 1387443073166000) into the database.
took this a different direction
Last call for comments before I merge this.
go for it
Looks good but I reserve the right to bikeshed when you implement query/collector using this api
As long as we paint it blue
What kind of testing has this undergone?
Unit tests and I spun up the example on my system to check that the ZK announcer was working properly. More is coming, but I wanted to get this in front of eyes.
I don't see the adaptive sampler in here.
+1 thanks for the fix!
It's not in here just yet. It's a complicated enough piece of code that I think it deserves a separate review anyway.

Yeah, this is related to other issues where some work unit will get enqueued to be executed later, such as a web submission that spawns (or contributes to) a hadoop job an hour later.  It would be nice to link individual traces together if they are related.
Final iteration of this.
Ok, done.  Looks pretty good.  Despite my nits, I say shipit.

#shipit
Note query and collector too when the time comes.
Also I wouldn't mind getting somebody who knows storm to review this, because I'm only mildly aware of what I'm looking at.
Rolled this into #327
It used to be possible to run zipkin without ZK.  Are we now saying that it's impossible?  Maybe we should provide a built in in-memory ZK for stand-alone clusters?
It's still possible. ZK is only required for certain uses.

Regarding the rate calculate, I'm trying to re-write this in a way that's pretty much a drop in replacement for what already exists. I plan on revisiting later. When we move to the new storage backend, it's likely we wont need to sample anyway.

The standard approach to this is to have all servers on UTC time and ntpd running to sync the times. We do try to "rejig" the times during display as best we can, but the assumption made is that the servers are reasonably in sync.
LGTM
Ship It!

This looks good, although reading this code makes me pine for a more unified data model for Spans/Traces/Annotations with perhaps a good Monoid definition or at least common manipulation methods for doing merging/intersecting/etc.
shipit
lgtm. use the script in bin to pull submit
lgtm +1

Substituting -D env=production for -D local_docroot=zipkin-web/src/main/resources did the trick for me:

java -cp libs -jar zipkin-web-1.1.0.jar -f config/web-dev.scala -D env=production

Did this break travis before or do we not compile it normally?
It did not break Travis. I need to add it. Docs in generally need a good updating.
Monoid is a subclass of Semigroup. That should not cause an error. What did you see?

You are correct. Monoid is not the root cause of the AbstractMethodError. After I updated the algebird version to 0.4.0, the error went away. Gonna just pump the algebird version and leave Monoid as it was.
This solved the issue for me :+1:

Sounds good.
